speech.p: I beg to move, in page 3, line 13, to leave out from "Minister," to "jointly,"in line 14, and to insert: "after consultation with the Treasury, shall. In Committee I accepted one of those Amendments which turns "may" into "shall."I do not say that it made any great difference to the Bill, but it made it mandatory rather than permissive upon the Commission to give compensation. Clause 3 dealt only with compensation that was paid before the winding-up. Clause 4 deals with compensation which is paid after the winding-up, and I gave a pledge in Committee to introduce appropriate words to bring this Clause into line with Clause 3, and to make it mandatory in both cases. This Amendment honours that pledge.

If we had known then what we know now about the passionate anxiety of the Raw Cotton Commission to pay compensation as fast as possible, perhaps we would not have put an Amendment on the Order Paper, but we were grateful to the President of the Board of Trade for his promise then, and we accept the Amendment with pleasure now.
Amendment agreed to.

Further Amendment made: In page 3, line 19, at end, insert: and who satisfy such conditions in respect of their service with the Commission as may be specified in the directions."—[Mr. P. Thorneycroft.]
Motion made, and Question proposed, "That the Clause, as amended, stand part of the Bill."

I do not think that we should allow this very important Clause to go without some further examination. Here is a Clause which, after the rest of the Bill has stripped the Raw Cotton Commission of many of their previous powers and obligations, provides for the eventual dissolution of the Commission, but between now and that time, the Commission remain in being. It is, therefore, very important indeed that the Committee should consider the way in which the Commission shall eventually cease to exist and the criteria which shall determine the time at which they shall cease to exist.
The Clause says: The Board and the Minister, if at any time they are satisfied that it is in the public interest to do so,… The rest is consequential. There are some points, no doubt, in the consequences, but nothing in this Clause is more important than the governing words that the Board and the Minister must be satisfied that it is in the public interest to bring the Commission to an end.
Let us consider these words, "in the public interest," very carefully, because this Bill has been treated a great deal by the Press and, I think, by some hon. Members of this House as if it concerned Lancashire only. It does concern Lancashire very vitally indeed. It affects Lancashire's principal industry and affects it, in our opinion, very adversely, but it is a Bill which affects the economic state of the whole country, and not only of this country but of other countries as well.
It was very fitting that my hon. Friend the Member for Deptford (Sir L. Plummer), at an earlier stage in our proceedings, caught your eye, Sir Rhys, and referred to the fact that he was not a Lancashire Member. Neither am I, but it is right that the voice of the rest of Britain should be heard in connection with this Bill because it does and it will affect the whole of the United Kingdom.
It so happens that this great industry is centred almost entirely in the county of Lancashire, but it is one of the principal industries of Great Britain, and what happens to Lancashire affects all the rest of us. It not only affects all the rest of us, but the prevalence of unemployment in Lancashire might mean the beginning of a depression, which
would undoubtedly affect the steel workers whom I have the honour to represent in Middlesbrough; and, more than that, it would affect our fellow citizens in the United Kingdom and in the Colonies which produce the cotton that Lancashire consumes.
It would affect the steelworkers of Middlesbrough even more quickly through that channel than it would through the first channel of unemployment, because if these countries which supplyus with cotton were to find difficulty in continuing to sell us cotton, their ability to buy the steel rails and other products of Middlesbrough's exporting industries would be very seriously impaired. We all have a common interest in this matter. It is apublic interest, and we want to examine tonight what that public interest is; what criteria the Minister and the Board can bring to bear in deciding when it is in the public interest to finish this Commission altogether.
I wish that we had with us this evening the advantage of the presence of the Secretary of State for the Colonies. He would have a double interest in this matter, because in 1947, when I introduced the original Bill, he led the Opposition throughout all stages of the Bill's consideration. He, therefore, knows a great deal about the Bill itself and the structure of the Raw Cotton Commission.
Whose Bill is it? Look at the empty benches opposite.

We can understand the argument of my right hon. Friend that this affects other parts of the country. There is no doubt that that is correct, but one would have thought, and I am sure that my right hon. Friend will agree with me, that it would have interested some of the Tory Members from Lancashire sufficiently for them to have had at least one of their Members present.
On a point of order. May I draw attention to the fact that there are not 40 Members present, Sir Rhys?
No, to do so now would be out of order.

Whatever time of the evening it may be, there is a conspicuous emptiness on the benches opposite which certainly deserves to be noticed in the way it has been.
I was saying that the Secretary of State for the Colonies has a special responsibility here although, of course, I do not complain about his personal inability to be present, because it may be that he has other matters directly calling for his attention. We know only too well the difficulties with which he is faced in so many of the Colonies at the present time. It is a pity, nevertheless, that he could not have been here to hear the cogent arguments which were advanced earlier this evening about the great public interest of the Colonies in the continued existence of even a truncated and attenuated Commission.
It will be remembered that the President of the Board of Trade caused consternation in the House, and will, I think, cause consternation among large sections of opinion in the Colonies, by his announcement tonight that, although there are arguments for long-term bulk purchase—[HON. MEMBERS: "Hear, hear."] I am delighted to see the hon. Member for Cheadle (Mr. Shepherd) come in, because I had thought of referring for a moment to some of the things he said.
The President's deliberate announcement tonight that "I have made it absolutely clear that we are not renewing these long-term contracts" will cause consternation in many of the Colonies, not only those which may at the moment have long-term contracts and bulk purchase arrangements, but those which have had them in the past and who hope to have them in the future.
The hon. Member for Cheadle sought to argue that these long-term contracts had often been quite useful in the past and were all right to help an infant industry growing up in a Colony, but that they had no special value at present and were no longer necessary. There is certainly no intention on this side of the House to force cotton producers in Uganda, for example, to sell their cotton in bulk under long-term contracts to the United Kingdom.
We do not want to exploit our Colonies. If they feel that it is to their advantage and in their public interest to sell in some other way, well and good. But we do not want to take away, in the manner that the right hon. Gentleman is doing, the opportunity for Uganda to sell in that way again if it wishes to do so, or for
the Sudan, Aden, the West Indian Sea Islands, and all the others who at present do it. The value of long-term contracts in the past is not denied by anybody to night. We say that those existing contracts ought not to be determined, because they are still of value, and a situation ought not to be created in which nobody in this country is able to resume long-term contracts in the future if the colonial producers desire to have them.
We have to ask ourselves what the President and the Minister of Materials are likely to judge to be the public interest in regard to the dissolution of the Commission. One example which we have had already leads us to believe that they will judge the public interest absolutely wrongly and that they will fail to take into account the public interest in that wide sense that I have described it, the interest of the whole of the United Kingdom and of overseas producers for whom the United Kingdom has had some responsibility in other countries.
The outstanding example is the story of the Sudan. My right hon. Friend the Member for Huyton (Mr. H. Wilson), in the first meeting of the Committee upstairs, predicted that great difficulties would occur in obtaining for Lancashire spinners who use Sudan cotton sufficient supplies of that cotton now that the Commission was being dismantled. He predicted that that would happen, and our prediction, unfortunately, came true all too soon.
We felt that that might happen, and on 3rd December my right hon. Friend asked the Minister of State, Board of Trade, a Question: what arrangements he is making for the purchase of Sudan and Peruvian cotton…for the 1954 season. The reply said, among other things: The Raw Cotton Commission…will make purchases from the 1954 Sudanese and Peruvian crops sufficient to meet any requirements of contractors-in until the 1955 crops become available…"—OFFICIAL REPORT, 3rd December, 1953; Vol, 521, c. 173.] That was the promise—that there would be "sufficient to meet any requirements.

Again, in our sitting upstairs on Thursday, 3rd December, the President of the Board of Trade said: steps are being taken in the Commission to see that adequate stocks of Sudanese cotton
are held to tide over the transition period between public and private buying."—OFFICIAL REPORT, Standing Committee A, 3rd December, 1953; c. 35.] That was the promise that was definitely made. But yesterday we were astounded to read, in reply to a Question by my hon. Friend the Member for Kirkdale (Mr. Keenan) as to whether the Minister of State is aware that at the recent sale of Sudan cotton the whole of the cotton offered was bought up by the Egyptian merchants at prices which the Liverpool buyers would not pay, the answer by the right hon. Gentleman that I understand that most of the comparatively small quantity of cotton offered at the recent auction in Khartoum was bought by export merchants who are resident in Egypt. Several of these firms are now offering the same cotton for re-sale to importers in Europe, including the United Kingdom. The Raw Cotton Commission and other United Kingdom importers are free to buy Sudanese cotton as they think fit, and my noble Friend is not prepared to advise them on the exercise of their commercial judgment."—OFFICIAL REPORT, 16th February, 1954; Vol. 523, c. 198–9.]

In December, therefore, we had the solemn and definite promise that the Sudanese and Peruvian cotton would be bought in sufficient quantity to tide the merchants over. In February, however, we are told, "We did not go in there. We did not buy this particular cotton. Of course, we had no kind of contract or agreement remaining, and we could not get hold of it. Now, these fellows have bought it up and are offering it at excessive prices. I do not know what can be done, but we can leave our importers to exercise their commercial judgment."

What a way to fulfil a promise to see that adequate stocks are provided. What an example of careless treatment of a vital Lancashire industry to set before the House. That is the sort of criterion which will be brought to bear by the Minister of Materials and the President of the Board of Trade when they come to exercise their duty to consider the public interest, as is provided under the Clause.

That, of course, is only one side of the story. I am not suggesting that the sole purpose of the existence of the Commission and its sole duty in the few months of life that remain to it should be to look after the interests of colonial or other overseas producers—not at all.

It is a two-way traffic; the interdependence is complete. One of the most important features of the whole situation is that many of the contractors-in who have remained faithful to the Commission are the very spinners who need these types of cotton—the types of cotton produced in Uganda, Nigeria, the West Indies, or wherever it may be, and in the Sudan, in particular.

It is that kind of spinner—a specialist very often, I believe, but I do not claim technical knowledge—who has remained loyal to the Commission, who wants the Commission to continue, and whose voice we heard for a moment or two from an hon. Member on the benches opposite, who is not at the moment present and whose constituency, unfortunately, I do not know
My right hon. Friend means the hon. and learned Member for Bolton, East (Mr. Philip Bell).
He has a "rocky" seat.

I do not wish to say that his anxiety to see that cotton was preserved for Bolton was due solely to his anxiety about maintaining his seat. I feel sure that he spoke sincerely in pointing out to the House the dangers of the present situation.
The case which we advance is that the Raw Cotton Commission ought to be kept in being for the special needs of this particular type of producer. We should have liked to see the whole of the Commission kept in existence, as laid down with thought and care in the original Act. But we accept that at this stage of the Bill that cannot now be done, and that the Commission must be stripped of some of its functions. We say that even that part which still remains ought now to be kept in existence, and ought not to be brought to an end by a decision of Ministers at any time they may think fit.
As my right hon. Friend the Member for Huyton has said, we have seen again and again that Ministers are not prepared to consider the public interest at all, because they have already made up their minds. They already decided months ago before they knew what the circumstances could possibly be that they were going to bring the Commission to an end, probably this year. That is not
the way in which serious responsible Ministers, entrusted by Parliament with great powers and great responsibilities for the public welfare, should decide what the public interest is.
We have had many examples of the careless, haphazard way in which the whole business of the supply of raw cotton for Lancashire has been handled, and we have had few displays of real interest about continuing to have regard to the welfare of our colonial producers of cotton. So little indication have we had of the proper understanding of the needs of the small spinners and specialist spinners who use the fine cotton produced in the Sudan and elsewhere that we have no confidence whatever in the ability of Her Majesty's Ministers to judge the public interest in the proper way. Therefore, we oppose the inclusion of this Clause in the Bill.

As I was saying before, all of us in this Committee are united in our desire to see that schemes for the economic development of the Colonies shall succeed, and because of the experience that I have had of line extreme difficulty of these schemes establishing themselves within a reasonable space of time I had begun to discuss the Sudan Gezira Scheme, which I have described as being the most promising and encouraging of all schemes that have been introduced, because it has a proper admixture of Government technicians, native producers and all the rest of it. I hope that I shall now be able to give the Committee some assistance and some information on its value, arising out of the information that I have had from the Sudan itself.
I ought to make it clear that the importance of Sudan cotton, apart from its importance to the Sudanese, is very great to Lancashire. The hon. and learned Member for Bolton, East (Mr. Philip Bell) expressed to me his regret that he had to go. After what he said to me it was quite clear that if he had heard my speech he would have had a different view and would have made an entirely different speech. He was concerned about the situation which was going to arise when Sudan cotton does not arrive any more. That concerns all of us. More than half the long staple cotton used in Lancashire today comes
from the Sudan. In 1950–51, 38 per cent. of it was used, but in the year 1952–53 75 per cent. was used.
One thing that Lancashire must have is Sudanese cotton, and I know my hon. Friend the Member for Ashton-under-Lyne (Mr. Rhodes) put the point with great vehemence, sincerity and conviction that it is absolutely necessary for the Sudan to be able to sell this cotton in an orderly manner. People whoare running the Gezira scheme do not want to have to go round gambling on the markets for the sale of their cotton. They are engaged in long-term schemes and continuing where the famous Arthur Gaitskell left off in the provision of social services, houses, roads and all the rest of the things which are necessary. We must listen to these people.
When my hon. Friend the Member for Ashton-under-Lyne was putting the case for the producers in the Colonies and overseas who wanted a continuance of the conditions and facilities provided by the Cotton Commission, his arguments were treated as though they were dubious. In view of that I think it would be right and proper if I were to read, with his permission, extracts from a letter sent to me by Mr. George W. Raby,the Chairman and Managing Director of the Sudan Gezira Board, which comes from Barakat in the Blue Nile Province of the Sudan.
Mr. Raby is well known to many people as an organiser and engineer of some considerable skill and experience, I might tell the Committee that he is not a Socialist. That is one quality in which he is lacking, otherwise he is an invaluable public servant, and he has proved it in the past. This is what he says: (1) There is not a bale of cotton in stock in Lancashire other than the R.C.C. holding. That confirms what was said by my hon. Friend the Member for Ashton-under-Lyne. (2) The Liverpool Exchange cannot hope to become a stable entity and provide a sufficient hedge for long staple cottons—such as the Sudans and Egyptians—for at least 18 months and possibly longer. (3) The larger consumers may be wealthy enough to be able to find the money to buy in reasonable stocks, but how are the small users to finance such stocks? Any borrowing of money would have to be at a low rate of interest otherwise they will be put out of business. (4) Closing down the R.C.C. so quickly leaves Lancashire with no intermediate Agency,
for all the old Cotton brokers who used to look after their individual clients' supplies have long since disappeared, with the result that everyone is dependent on the Exporter-Importer merchants who would have no particular fancy for the Lancashire Raw Cotton trade if better prices could be obtained elsewhere in the world. I think the most telling argument is that henceforth many small and medium sized fine-spinners will have to finance their stocks with money at present allocated for machinery improvement and replacements, and you can get confirmation of this from a friend of mine." He then gives the name of this particular friend. He goes on to give me some more information which he asks me not to disclose because he thinks it would help us on this side of the Committee rather than those on the other side of the Committee. Above all, Mr. Raby wants to be impartial.

Here is a man who, in his earnestness to be heard by the ear of this House, sends me at the same time a letter from Messrs. Crosses and Heatons, Limited, Chorley New Road, Bolton. Bolton comes into this rather as Denmark comes into Hamlet. This is clearly the concern of Bolton. This is what this firm, Crosses and Heatons, Limited, wrote on 21st December last year, to the Director of the Federation of Master Cotton Spinners' Associations Limited—

p.q: The transitional period from the R.C.C. to free buying is bound to entail some risk, but in our opinion these risks should be reasonable ones and it would be to everyone's benefit to see the change over made as smoothly as possible. To have this transitionary period for Group II cottons too short can only be disastrous.

speech.p: Sudanese cottons are included in this classification. We should like to see the life of the R.C.C. Merchanting Sections and merchanting facilities extended for at least twelve months or until such time as it is possible to open a 'long staple' futures contract…

The chairman and managing director of the Sudan Gezira Board says to this House through me that what we must have over the next 18 months is a planned and orderly purchase of the product that he is producing under difficult conditions for really important and serious ends. His letter, coming from such an expert, and written without prejudice or bias, is my justification for intervening in this debate. I commend the letter to the Committee.
Notice taken that 40 Members were not present;
House counted, and, 40 Members being present—

Now that we have finished with the count, Sir Rhys, I rise to address the Committee on the Question, "That the Clause, as amended, stand part of the Bill."
I want to express my appreciation to my hon. Friend the Member for Ashton-under-Lyne (Mr. H. Rhodes) for drawing an audience, however temporary, including at least one Lancashire Conservative Member. The small attendance of hon. Gentlemen opposite is rather disappointing in view of the fact that the discussion on this Clause in Committee upstairs was a somewhat circumscribed one; indeed, the Government would not have got the Clause if it had not been for the co operation of my hon. Friends on this side of the Committee.
I wish to follow what my hon. Friend the Member for Deptford (Sir L. Plummer) has said on a matter of profound importance to this country, to Lancashire and, indeed, to the world. It is a fact that despite the educative progress which has gone on throughout the Committee stage, as a result of which I assume that the Minister of State, Board of Trade, anyway has learnt something, the Government are still unaware of the consequences of the action which is envisaged in this Clause. We have already had an account of how they will affect Lancashire spinners, and I want to look at the potential effect on the lives of some of the workers in places like Preston and Bolton, whose anxiety as to the future has been continuously and repeatedly increased, and whose confidence has been repeatedly shaken by the action of this Government.
I do not need to refer in detail to the recent Japanese Agreement, but I shall deal with two or three points which even now have not yet been answered by the Government, and I hope that the right hon. Gentleman will give us some answer. First, how are these spinners who have not the capital available to finance their stocks going to manage? It is still one of the great delusions of the Government, and indeed of much of the industry, that
finance is available, largely because it is available to those who are in a strong position. It is not available to those who are in a weak position.
It is very often not available for important exports. The chance of the finance not being available without those concerned having to draw on other capital which may be available and other resources which they should be using at this moment to increase their competitive efficiency, will weaken Lancashire. I hope that the Minister will have a word to say on the stock position.
There is a more serious angle to the stock position, which was mentioned in another context by, I think, my hon. Friend the Member for Blackburn, East (Mrs. Castle). [An Hon. Member: "It cannot be West."] No, because the right hon. Member for Blackburn, West (Mr. Assheton) is not here. He is rarely with us. It is with regard to the limited supplies of raw materials where a quota scheme may be enforced or some restriction may exist.
I do not quite see how the hon. Member is relating that to the provisions of this Clause.

Indeed, it is very relevant to the Clause because I am coming to the question of whether it is wise at the moment to allow this Clause to stand part of the Bill. The argument which I am deploying is in relation to the possibility of a shortage of imported raw materials for the Lancashire cotton industry resulting from the closing down of the Raw Cotton Commission.
Repeatedly, throughout our discussions in Committee, we have been watching the progress of economic forces in the world and the increasing dangers of an American slump. Throughout the whole of this period we have been regaled with soft stories of how this slump would never come, but we have heard in recent days that the down-turn in American production is as high as 10 per cent. Even the American Government are talking seriously about a slump in America. If that should come the effect on this country's dollar situation may be very serious. It is at this very moment, when we may have the greatest difficulty in buying our raw cotton supplies, that we may be without the essential organisation to buy and
distribute it. And we know only too well how unsatisfactorily quota schemes are being worked in the few sections of industry where they apply today.
I do not believe that small spinners and others in Lancashire would have the confidence in the Liverpool cotton merchants to believe that they would have a fair deal. They certainly would not have the confidence in them which they had in the Raw Cotton Commission. It is at this moment that this Government, despite these warnings, are persevering in their decision to close the Raw Cotton Commission. It is extremely difficult to see how they can justify that at a moment like this.
We have already had many arguments about the effect abroad. I can only conclude that hon. Members opposite are so fascinated by the operation of the commodity markets that they sit looking at the Liverpool Exchange like a man who tries to invent a perpetual motion machine and believes that it is a valuable thing. They take the ingenuity and exciting quality of the Liverpool Cotton Exchange as something of validity and value. But Lancashire is not interested in that. Lancashire wants cotton for the operatives in the mills.
This Clause is the one Clause which will continue to spread alarm and anxiety about the future in Lancashire. Even at this late stage I ask the Minister to consider some of the arguments which have been put forward from this side of the Committee and to give an answer to the question of how, in the event of a serious economic recession, he hopes to provide raw cotton equitably for the workers in Lancashire.

I want to make my second appeal to the Minister of State, Board of Trade, this evening. I can do it quite well on this Motion. It is that in respect of those members of the spinning industry with unit mills who have been relying on the Raw Cotton Commission to get cotton for them. Between now and the time it is decided to make an order, whenever that may be, it should be made clear to those mills that their supplies will be assured.
We have already discussed the question of purchases in Uganda and elsewhere. Spinners have not exercised the option to buy for themselves in certain markets
—the Sudan and Uganda—as has been proved by the letter from Mr. Raby, the head of the Gezira Board. The liquidation of the Raw Cotton Commission some time during the next 12 months will spell disaster, as I have pointed out repeatedly to the Committee, to those unit mills relying on the Commission for their supplies of cotton.
Is it not ridiculous that the very people who have been agitating for the removal of the Commission so that they can get back to the pre-war system of buying in the open market, have not even exercised the privilege of purchasing, so much so that at present—after two seasons with the opportunity to purchase privately—they have not got the stocks, but the Raw Cotton Commission have stocks?
Surely it is not common sense, nor is it just, to say that those firms which have remained loyal to the Commission and by conviction and also through expediency have continued to buy from the Commission should suddenly be jettisoned and thrown overboard without any regard for their future. That is about to happen. For the sake of their reputation, I appeal to the Minister tonight to take this point very seriously and consider it with the point I made about economic colonial cottons in the futures contracts. He will find that this will pay handsome dividends, and hon. Members opposite like that. I implore him tonight to take that point because it will stand him in good stead in the months and years to come.

I want to say a word or two on the points which have been made by hon. Members opposite, to which I have listened with great attention. The hon. Member for Ashton-under-Lyne (Mr. Rhodes) is pursuing a path on the question of financial responsibility parallel to the path he pursued on the question of the grower. Let us face the fact that on the two sides of the Committee we are diametrically opposed in our purposes. Our view on this side of the Committee is—I state it without hesitation—that as far as possible we want the ordinary interplay of economic forces to run business.
Hon. Gentlemen opposite believe that business cannot be run without "mothering" and "marming." We do not agree.

Even if there were any question of the ability of mills to purchase their stocks, the hon. Member is guilty of gross exaggeration. If he and I could have a confidential talk about those firms in the Lancashire textile industry, the spinners, who could not afford to buy the stocks required, how many would we find?
Will the hon. Member give way?

No. Let me pursue this.
If we say we would find four or five, that, in my opinion, would be a high estimate. Is that a reason why we should continue this extraordinary apparatus of State buying? When you are in business you have to buy your raw materials—everyone has to buy his materials—and provide means of financing the operation. Is it really right to provide that the Lancashire cotton industry—which, after all, is one of the most prosperous industries in the country today—shall be mothered in this way? Because it may be proved that three or four, or five or six, at any rate a comparatively small number of firms, find difficulty—I do not say that any firm will find it impossible—in adapting themselves to the new circumstances, are we to maintain this paraphernalia of State organised buying?

I did not make any plea to the Minister on account of inability to finance on this occasion. I did in the Standing Committee, but not now. Now it is a matter of actually getting the cotton. I pointed out that those merchants who have had the opportunity to purchase cotton during the last two years have not done so. Who are the people from whom the firms are to buy their cotton when the Commission finish if it is not the merchants? And if the merchants are not doing their job, what hope is there for the trade? We shall be short of cotton.

Now the hon. Member is introducing another point, but I am willing to deal with it. We have been over the ground a number of times about the fact that stocks of a particular type of cotton in the hands of private merchants are not as satisfactory as we should like. But the hon. Gentleman must try to face this thing realistically. Were he a merchant, how would he like to start competing in the buying of certain growths of cotton against a Commission
capable of losing £25 million in one year and another £25 million the next year?
It is no use laying a complaint against the private merchant when he is in the position of having to face a large buying organisation which can afford to lose, and has indeed, lost, £25 million in two successive years. There may be merchants who can afford to enter into that sort of competitive buying, but I do not know any, and, therefore, I do not attach great importance to the fact that, in the existing circumstances, there may be difficulty in obtaining stocks of Sudan cotton from private merchants.
What the argument of the hon. Gentleman did prove and fortify is the case against this Amendment—
What Amendment?
The Amendment we have been discussing before this one—
It is out of order to discuss any Amendment. We are now debating the Question, "That the Clause, as amended, stand part of the Bill."

I will content myself by saying that it does not fortify the argument against the Bill. It is impossible for any hon. Member on this side of the Committee to expect a merchant to stock up when there is a large buyer, like the Raw Cotton Commission, able to lose £25 million a year. I hope that my right hon. Friend will in no way delay the application of this Measure, but that at the earliest possible moment he will start the machinery of the Liverpool Cotton Exchange, so that the merchants may be properly covered and have confidence in buying their stocks, and be enabled to give that service which Lancashire deserves.

Is it not a fact that the hon. Member for Cheadle (Mr. Shepherd) is putting to the Committee, in as delicate a way as possible, the doctrine of a return to Adam Smith, the laissez faire doctrine which Keynes buried in 1925, and which every intelligent person in this country—
Order. Any reference to Adam Smith is entirely remote from the Question before the Committee.

Will the hon. Member for Cheadle answer this question? Time and time again hon. Members opposite have put to the Opposition the argument that we have departed from what the Commission was originally intended to do. It was originally intended to ensure an even flow of cotton at an even price. We have been taunted about going back to a replacement price. The Commission has been working on a replacement price for many months now. If that is so, what happens to the hon. Gentleman's argument about competition, for there cannot be any?
I cannot go over the ground again—
On a point of order, Sir Rhys. When you called me to order just now on a point which you said was outside the Question that we are discussing, I had not finished my intervention.
As far as the intervention had gone, it was out of order. I think we have disposed of it now.

Perhaps I might be allowed to draw my remarks to a close. I know that hon. Members opposite are most anxious to get on. I listened to them for some weeks in Committee upstairs, and I know how desperately anxious they are to speed up the Bill.
I cannot understand the anxiety of hon. Members opposite about the supply of stocks. If one is a cotton merchant, one makes profits by supplying cotton, and profit is a very strong stimulus. If a cotton merchant does not supply cotton, he does not make any money. Surely one thing that we can agree upon is that cotton merchants want to make money. I am certain that, when the transition period has passed, the supply of cotton to the Lancashire mills will be satisfactory to all concerned. We have met far too many obstacles before we have reached them. I am sure that within six to eight months of the passing of the Bill and the setting up again of the Commission the fears of hon. Gentlemen opposite will have been proved to be groundless.

No one would expect me to follow the line taken by the hon. Member for Cheadle (Mr. Shepherd). If we carry one part of his argument to its
logical conclusion, he disagrees with his own Front Bench and is suggesting that we should not even honour the long-term contracts that we have at present, which the Government are prepared to do. My hon. Friend the Member for Ashton-under-Lyne (Mr. Rhodes) seems to provoke the hon. Member for Cheadle. It is always after my hon. Friend has spoken that the hon. Member for Cheadle decides to intervene in these debates.
I wish to call attention to Clause 4(1), which says: The Board and the Minister, if at any time they are satisfied that it is in the public interest to do so, may by order jointly provide for the winding up and dissolution of the Commission.… The Opposition are not convinced that the Government will know when it is in the public interest to wind up the Commission. We are convinced that the Government do not know when it is in the interest of the cotton industry to take action. We are convinced in any case that if they had had the interests of the cotton industry at heart the Government would never have brought forward the Bill. We had evidence of this in the Government's handling of the Japanese Trade Agreement, but I will not go into that matter for fear that I shall be ruled out of order.
With regard to the public interest, and, more particularly, the interests of Lancashire and Cheshire, there are three problems which are closely bound up. I have never yet had a satisfactory answer about any of them. We have discussed them repeatedly in Committee, but we do not seem to be able to get a very satisfactory answer.
I am not quite certain yet whether the Government now consider that we have a balance of payments problem or not, or whether they consider that the whole question of the balance of payments and the dollar problem has been solved. I really do not know what the Chancellor of the Exchequer might say about this Bill and its possible effects, but it might have been very helpful if, in one of our debates, the Chancellor had told us about the possible effects of this Bill in relation to the problem of the balance of payments.
Secondly, there is the question of stocks. In spite of what the hon. Member for Cheadle said about stocks and the fears of the mills, I suggest to him and
to the Government that they should read what the trade union leaders have had to say about the stock position and their fear that the industry might break down because of a lack of stocks.
I want to come now to the third problem, the question of the Colonies and colonial development. On the Amendment to page 3, line 12, which we discussed earlier, the debate was restricted because the words "long-term contracts" were included, and, therefore, we were not able to mention certain of the Colonies, because the argument was used that there was no long-term agreement with those Colonies. To take, first, the British West Indies, which subjectwas ruled out of order in the earlier debate because it was said there was no long-term contract. If there is an agreement with the British West Indies extending over a number of years whereby the Raw Cotton Commission have been buying the crop before it is sown, to me that is the equivalent of a long-term agreement.
In any case, it is vitally important to the West Indies that we should continue to take their crop from Montserrat, St Nevis and Anguilla, because cotton is the main export and, second only to sugar, in the case of Antigua and to arrowroot in the case of St. Vincent. Whether it is a principal or a second crop, it is vitally important to us, and these islands are dependent upon the help which they can get from us in this country. The collapse of the industry would, therefore, mean that there would have to be further support from Her Majesty's Government in order to help them to balance their finances.
Let us make clear what has happened in the last three years, and what has been the effect which the half-and-half system of the Raw Cotton Commission and private buying has had on the import of Sea Island cotton from the British West Indies. I am, of course, referring to long staple, which is Sea Island cotton. In 1951, we imported 22,294 centals of100 lb. each; in 1952, it had gone down to 21,610 centals; but in 1953, it was down to 6,021. This is a very serious matter for the West Indies.

I have here a report prepared by the advisory committee in England of the West Indian Sea Island Cotton Association. It was prepared to deal with the
question of Purchase Tax, but it is relevant to what I have to say. It says: At the time these difficulties were not directly felt in the West Indies, since all cotton was purchased by the Raw Cotton Commission; and to assist the Islands each year the Raw Cotton Commission purchased the whole crop of each island in advance at remunerative prices, negotiated with the negotiating committee of the Association. Recently, however,— and this is the point to which I want to call attention— the action of the Government in allowing spinners to contract out of obtaining their supplies of raw cotton from the Raw Cotton Commission has changed the position. Growers no longer have a guaranteed market and there has been a sharp fall in prices offered by spinners.
If the West Indies loses its guaranteed market, the whole economy of certain of the West Indian Islands is upset.

We are also inquiring into the details of the position of Uganda. There has been a phenomenal drop in the import into this country of Uganda cotton, from 466,447 centals in 1951 down to 201,371 centals in 1953. In monetary value, as my right hon. Friend the Member for Huyton (Mr. H. Wilson) said, the drop has been from £10,156,000 in 1951, down to £2,834,000 in 1953.
What has happened? During 1953, the import of cotton from Uganda by Japan went up by about 50 per cent. in one year. We have the position that sterling cotton is not coming to us from Uganda—
The hon. Member's argument is getting a little far from the Question before the Committee.
Might I put it this way, Sir Rhys? I was bringing forward the economic facts of what is happening to the Uganda market. The fact I was referring to was that Japan was buying sterling cotton.
We are discussing the Clause dealing with the dissolution of the Raw Cotton Commission.

Yes, Sir Rhys, but only when it is in the public interest to do so. My argument is designed to show that the Government do not appreciate that it is not in the public interest to do so.
However, rather than cause you further anxiety, and having made the point which I had in mind, I will leave my comments there, because I know there are other hon. Members who would like to make a contribution to the debate.

I wish to make only one or two very brief observations in reply to points that have been made, and I will not take up the time of the Committee in explaining any further why we believe it will be good to wind up the Commission, because that matter has already been very fully discussed.
The Government have never given the reason.

We have mentioned many times that, having announced our object to be the winding up of the Commission, it would be thoroughly bad to have continuing doubt and uncertainty. Therefore we announced that it was our view that it would be in the public interest that the Commission should be wound up as soon as practicable after 31st August next. The order will come forward in good time, and there will be plenty of opportunity for us to debate that subject further.
The right hon. Member for Middlesbrough, East (Mr. Marquand) took me to task because he said that we had made it clear that the Raw Cotton Commission would take care of the requirements of contractors in until the 1954 crop becomes available. That is so. We have said that, and the Raw Cotton Commission has made that very clear.
But the right hon. Gentleman appeared to think that that was difficult to reconcile with the answer which I gave in the House on 16th February, when I said: The Raw Cotton Commission…are free to buy Sudanese cotton as they think fit, and my noble Friend is not prepared to advise them on the exercise of their commercial judgment."—OFFICIAL REPORT, 16th February, 1954; Vol. 523, c. 199.] Surely, as the Raw Cotton Commission has said that they are going to cover these requirements, it would be quite superfluous to advise them how they should do so, and what quantities of Sudan cotton they require to buy to make good that assurance.
The hon. and gallant Member for Preston, South (Mr. Shackleton) pressed
me again about the financial aspects of stocks for the smaller spinners, a matter which I thought we had discussed fairly fully in Committee. My hon. Friend the Member for Cheadle (Mr. Shepherd) referred to that, and pointed out that it is a normal requirement for a concern in industry to be responsible for providing its own stocks. I do not think it is fair to expect the responsibility for that in respect of one industry, however important it may be, to fall on public funds.
I would point out that a firm requiring supplies of cotton has two alternatives. It can either buy them in advance and finance them itself, or it can buy spot. I am quite certain that the merchants in the Liverpool Cotton Association will be prepared to provide whatever stocks are required. Naturally, spinners must be prepared to pay the reasonable cost of providing that surplus, but, if spinners will only make their requirements clear in advance, I am quite certain that the merchants will provide the stocks, because, after all, that is how they earn their living.
The hon. and gallant Member also asked what would happen if, unfortunately, it became necessary to impose restrictions on the import of dollar cotton. I can only repeat what we said earlier, which was that if, unfortunately, that became necessary, and if the restrictions which had to be imposed were only moderate in extent, we believed it could be done within the framework of the Liverpool cotton market, and individual rationing through the entitlement system appears to us to point a way in which that could be done. If the restrictions had to be much more severe, then that would be a matter on which nation-wide special measures would have to be taken, because the problem goes much wider than the provision of raw cotton.
Then we come to the hon. Member for Ashton-under-Lyne (Mr. Rhodes), who is concerned, as he made clear this evening
Why this discrimination? Why not "gallant" as well?

I know of no one who has a better claim to that title if he would like to assume it.
The hon. Gentleman raised the aspect, not of finance, but of supplies. I know that he is genuinely concerned about
supplies, particularly of the Sudan and colonial types. Again, I would remind him of the assurance given by the Raw Cotton Commission that they are going to take care of the requirements of the contracting-in spinners for all types of cotton which they may require this season.
After that, in spite of having listened very carefully to what the hon. Gentleman said, I cannot see why spinners are going to find it any more difficult to obtain supplies of Sudan and colonial cotton than did the Raw Cotton Commission in the past. After all, the Raw Cotton Commission has never had long-term contracts for the provision of Sudan cotton. I am quite certain that, again, merchants will be only too glad to provide the service involved in the supply of these types of cotton if only spinners will make their requirements known.
The hon. Member for Stalybridge and Hyde (Mr. Blackburn) raised some questions about the West Indies and Uganda. As to the West Indies, I only want to say that up to 1951–52 the Raw Cotton Commission did buy bulk supplies from the West Indies—

If I might interrupt the right hon. Gentleman, he has just said quite categorically that the Raw Cotton Commission has never had long-term arrangements for buying from the Sudan. How then does he explain the statement in the Cotton Commission's annual report—which has already been quoted once this afternoon—stating: As mentioned earlier the Commission, in the autumn of 1951, decided to ensure Lancashire's future requirements of long staple cotton from the Sudan, and a bulk contract was negotiated…

It was annual, but bulk purchase is not the same as long term, and that is the difference. This, as Iunderstand it, is a perfectly clear case of a bulk purchase. Another bulk purchase may have been made the next year, but it is absolutely different from a long-term contract.
But surely the right hon. Gentleman—
Thequestion whether it is long-term contract or not is not relevant. It was relevant to the Amendment we were discussing before, because that phrase was included, but it is not relevant now.

With respect, in the succession of Rulings duringthe debate on the Amendment it was ruled that we could debate only the areas which were subjects of long-term contracts. Then the Government Front Bench took it upon themselves to define "long-term contracts"in a particular way, and we were then told it was appropriate to refer to it.

I raised the point about long-term contracts because the phrase was in the Amendment, but when we come to the Question "That the Clause, as amended, stand part of the Bill," that question does not arise.
With respect, when my hon. Friend the Member for Deptford (Sir L. Plummer) and others wanted to refer to the Sudan—

It was not in order then to discuss the Sudan. I am pointing out that in a discussion of the Question "That the Clause, as amended, stand part of the Bill," it is in order, because it does not matter whether it is long-term or not.
In that case, Sir Rhys, I find it difficult to understand why you pulled me up before.
Because the Amendment referred to long-term con-

tracts. On the Question "That the Clause, as amended, stand part of the Bill," the public interest is involved, and it does not matter whether it is a long-term or yearly contract. They are both included.

I was trying to deal with the point which the hon. Member for Stalybridge and Hyde raised about the West Indies. Up to 1951–52 there was bulk purchase, again, of West Indian long staple cotton. Since 1951–52 there has not been. But I am advised that the West Indies were offered a long-term contract and preferred not to have one. Much the same—not quite but nearly—applies to Uganda. Up to and including 1951–52 there was bulk purchase, but I understand, again, that Uganda prefers free buying to a long-term or bulk contract.
I shall not deal with the broad objects of this Clause, because we have really debated them at very considerable length, not only on Second Reading but in Committee, and I will not again deploy the arguments which we advanced on that occasion.
Question put, "That the Clause, as amended, stand part of the Bill."
The Committee divided: Ayes, 257: Noes, 242.

speech.p: Bill reported, with Amendments; as amended (in the Standing Committee, and on recommittal), considered.
Clause 1.—(FUNCTIONS OF RAW COTTON COMMISSION.)

I beg to move, in page 2, line 18, to leave out subsection (5).
I hope to keep the discussion on the Amendment very narrow. What subsection (5) does is to confer retroactive effect on the whole of the Clause. I do not propose to discuss in detail those subsections to which subsection (5) gives retrospective effect. I want to deal with the narrow point of retrospection, because the whole House will feel that wherever legislation has retrospective effect, it should be brought to the attention of the House and the House should be thoroughly satisfied about it.
In the Standing Committee, there was discussion on a similar Amendment to delete subsection (5), and on that occasion the debate was restricted so far as we were concerned to one point only, namely, to ask the President of the Board of Trade whether this meant that the Board of Trade had been acting illegally in using the 1947 Act for the purpose of permitting contracting-out, because there had been doubt about it in our debate last July. We adjourned the debate in Committee to get the attendance of a Law Officer of the Crown, who did not turn up, and after all that the Government stood firm to their view that there had been no illegality in the use of the 1947 Act for the purpose of introducing the system of contracting-out.
I do not want to pursue the point that we debated in Committee, but I wish to put one simple narrow question to the President, to which I hope he gives a clear answer. It is my suspicion that here again, possibly for the third time during the passage of the Bill, the President has been acting illegally. We spent some hours this afternoon debating Amendments that had been introduced to validate the action of the Commission, and I have referred also to problems about the winding up of the statistics department.
What is the purpose of subsection (5)? It is a retrospective subsection to say that the whole of the Clause shall be deemed to have come into operation on 1st September last. Why has the President put this in the Bill? Either it has meaning or it has not. If it has no meaning, obviously the President will accept our Amendment and will have the subsection deleted. If it has meaning, we must ask what it is.
It would appear to us on this side that if the President is by this retrospective subsection validating the actions of the Commission in that they have been defaulting on their obligations, which are referred in the previous four subsections, the Commission have once again been acting illegally. That is the only possible interpretation. I think it would be in order to do so, but I have no desire to discuss what those obligations are which are affected by subsection (5). I confine myself to the narrow point of why retrospection is involved.
Surely, this is the position. If not, I hope that the President will tell us. Under the original Act, the Commission were given a whole range of obligations. A whole range of things that they had to do is set out in summary form in subsections (1) to (4). Then, along comes the President, who makes all these alterations in the Commission's behaviour, who tells them to do all sorts of things, like contracting-out. He comes along with the Bill, and the Bill as a whole says that the Commission do not have to fulfil these obligations any more. All up to this point is quite understandable.

Then we find that subsection (5) states not only that the Commission need not fulfil their obligations any more, but that
they do not have to fulfil those obligations right back to last September. What does that mean? It can only mean, if this subsection has any validity at all, that the Raw Cotton Commission defaulted on the obligations referred to in subsection (1) since last September. If that is so, since this Bill is not yet law and the only law that governs the Raw Cotton Commission's behaviour is the 1947 Act, then the Commission have been defaulting on the obligations of the 1947 Act and was promised by the President that if it did default the Government would validate it with another retrospective Measure, namely, the present Bill.

In submitting that the Commission have operated illegally, I would add that what we fear is that what has been happening here is far worse than the sort of thing we were talking about this afternoon. We all understand what happened then. The Raw Cotton Commission slipped up. There was a lot of argument today about the relations between the President of the Board of Trade and the Commission. The President then introduced legislation to give restrospective validity to the Commission's action, which was ultra vires and which involved the paying out of compensation.

I do not want to say anything about that, because we have debated it. But what I fear is that under this subsection something much more serious has been at work. In fact, the Commission have been defaulting on their obligations as set out in the 1947 Act, not behind the back of the President of the Board of Trade but at his behest. He cannot say that he did not know about it, because this illegal behaviour has been committed ever since the 1st September so that the President himself must have been responsible for telling the Commission to break the law in that way. That is the only meaning I can read into the necessity for this subsection.

If the President will tell us that this subsection is not really necessary, that the Raw Cotton Commission have not yet started defaulting on their obligations, and will only do so when empowered by this Bill becoming law, then we shall be happy and he will be happy to accept this Amendment. If that is not the position and this is required because the Commission have been defaulting on their obligations, I
believe that a serious state of affairs will be revealed because it will have been done at his behest.

May I ask the President to deal specifically with this point? I have not attempted to go into the question of what those obligations are, but will he tell us whether at this time the Raw Cotton Commission are or are not defaulting on the obligations which were laid upon them by the 1947 Act? If he tells us that they have not defaulted, then we want to know why he is taking this retrospective action. If he tells us they have defaulted, then it will be a grave statement of which the House will have to take notice.

Clause 1, as the right hon. Member for Huyton (Mr. H. Wilson) quite accurately points out, removes a number of the obligations which were imposed on the Commission, and very properly imposed, when they were operating as a monopoly. But in the course of time the Commission have ceased to be a monopoly, not all at once but over a period of time.
When it reported, the first Hopkins Committee brought the Raw Cotton Commission to an end as a monopoly because that committee, which represented all sections of the industry, recommended that those who wished to contract out should be allowed to do so, and about one-third of them did. The second Hopkins Committee examined this again and recommended, broadly, speaking, the same procedure. On the second contracting out more than 50 per cent. of the trade did so and it is clear that in those circumstances there was no longer a monopoly.
It is possible under the Act to issue licences to those contractors out so that they can purchase on private account, but when we are dealing with a Bill which, in effect, ends the monopoly Obligations—because this is what it does in the period between now and the ending of the Commission—it is wise to take account of the facts of the situation. They are not facts of politics, but really facts of nature.
On 1st September the buying season starts. That is why that date was chosen, so that spinners could make up their minds whether they would buy from the
Cotton Commission or not. So that on 1st September, 1953, roughly 50 per cent. of the trade decided that they would buy outside. Therefore, when we came to the drafting of the Bill, we took account of these facts of nature and said that as from that date the obligations of the Cotton Commission would no longer rest upon them.
I think that was the wise and sensible thing to do. Nothing illegal has taken place because it is legitimate under the terms of the original Act. The right hon. Gentleman himself said in an earlier debate that he thought we were straining the spirit of the law. I think this subsection takes cognisance of that point of view. At any rate, it takes account of the fact that as from 1st September, 1953, so much of the trade was buying on private account that one could not say that from that time monopoly obligations should be placed on the Commission. In those circumstances, I hope the House will retain the subsection.

Will the right hon. Gentleman answer my question, because it is absolutely fundamental to this Amendment? Is it a fact, or is it not, that since 1st September the Raw Cotton Commission have not been carrying out the obligations which, however contrary to the facts of nature or whatever the right hon. Gentleman calls them, are still the law? Have they been honouring fully all the obligations which are the law of the land as set out in the 1947 Act?

They have been honouring to the full their obligations under the Act, and we have been meticulously careful to see that all the various procedures laid down under the original Act have been complied with.

I do not want to follow the point raised by my right hon. Friend, but I cannot feel satisfied that the right hon. Gentleman has given a satisfactory reply. This Clause is important in two respects. First, it brings forward once again the risk of retrospective legislation. It is agreed on all sides that it is undesirable that there should be retrospective legislation and that it is derogatory to the rule of law that what is believed and understood at any given time to be the law should afterwards be decided by Parliament not to have been the law. It is a
principle on which all parties can agree and it is the duty of hon. Members to draw attention to contraventions of the principle when they occur.
The second and more important detailed consideration is that an arbitrary date has been inserted in the Bill, namely, 1st September, 1953. When we inquire why that date is selected we are told that the reason is that 1st September marks the beginning of the cotton year. The 1953 1st September marks the beginning of the period during which the scale of private importation of cotton reached the point of "over-straining the Act." The anxiety that we have felt during the consideration of this Bill is that when the Government talk about "over-straining the Act" what they mean, in fact, is breaking the law. That is what we think is the correct interpretation.
Contracting out in the year beginning 1st September, 1953, was carried out on a scale substantially over 50 per cent., and it is obviously something quite different in kind and degree from anything contemplated under the extension Sections in the original Act. But where very considerable anxiety still exists is on what the position was in the previous year, the cotton year which began on 1st September, 1952.
The President said this evening, as he said earlier upstairs with great confidence and certainty, that nothing illegal had occurred and, of course, it would be wasting the time of the House to start hares on a matter of that kind. If one had felt a real conviction that nothing illegal had been happening it would be rather a waste of time to pursue the point, but there are still some of us who are doubtful about it. We feel doubtful particularly about the events of that earlier cotton year when contracting out was not at 50 per cent. but about 30 per cent., which is not dealt with by the subsection which we have now under consideration.
It is said that a great deal of what was going on during that year was probably illegal, although there have been no prosecutions. One wonders how closely was fulfilled during that year the requirement of the principal Act that written permission should be received from the Raw Cotton Commission before private importation, and that licences
should be provided by the Board of Trade to cover every importation transaction.
What assurance have the Government been able to give on this point? The only assurance that they have given so far is that which was offered by the Minister of State, Board of Trade, to the Standing Committee when he said: To the best of my knowledge, an individual licence was given"— That was for the cotton year beginning 1st September, 1952— to each individual private operator but not, so far as I am aware, a separate licence for each individual transaction."—[OFFICIAL REPORT,Standing Committee A, 15th December, 1953; c. 136.] That is the confession of the Minister as to what has occurred.
We had the greatest difficulty in obtaining any information at all. When we pressed the matter that was the information that we received. He felt able to say that every individual operator had been the recipient of a licence, but he was quite unable to say that every single transaction had been made under a licence. I doubt very much whether that account of the matter, which comes from the Minister himself, at all meets the requirements of the principal Act. The Act does not say that private importations will be permitted when a licence is given to an operator. Not at all. If that had been the wording of the principal Act there would have been some ground for the Government coming forward now and saying that nothing illegal had occurred.

Let us look at what the principal Act says in this connection. Section 2 (1, d) of the principal Act provides that the overriding prohibition against private importation of cotton shall not apply "to a person acting in relation to the importation in question under the authority of a licence granted by the Board of Trade.…"

That clearly contemplates a licence in respect of every importation. I take the view, and expect it to be widely shared, that it simply did not meet the statutory requirement of the principal Act of 1947 to give an overall licence to the importer.

That is obviously what has occurred, on the confession of the Minister of State, Board of Trade. The Government treated the Section with a laxity of which, if it had occurred on this side
of the House, they would have been severely critical. They have given the operator, the importer, the merchant a wide overall licence or discretion and such behaviour was not contemplated by the principal Act, which specifically brought in the words in relation to the importation in question.

I think there is point of substance there. It would have been very wrong if this consideration of the Bill had gone through without that point being brought forward. It is on record now and I should not like it to be thought that the suave assurance of the President that nothing illegal had occurred carried as much weight as apparently he thought it did.

I say this about the subsection we seek to remove. It is objectionable in principle, because, once again, it introduces the objectionable principle of retrospective legislation. I say that it is purporting to make legal acts which have been carried out since 1st September, 1953, and which, if executed before that time, were illegal. To the extent to which it is an indemnity Clause it is not effective because it does not go far enough as it fails to cover the manifest illegality which occurred in the cotton year commencing 1st September, 1952.
Question put, "That the words proposed to be left out stand part of the Bill."
The House divided: Ayes, 252; Noes, 241.

speech.p: Clause 3.—(COMPENSATION TO OFFICERS, AGENTS AND SERVANTS OF COMMISSION.)

I beg to move, in page 3, line 5, at the end, to insert: Provided that no such approval shall be given to any scheme or arrangement under this part of this Act which provides that officers, agents or servants of the Commission shall be compensated for loss of employment at rates or on a basis of calculation which discriminates between those whose remuneration is paid or calculated weekly and those whose remuneration is paid or calculated monthly, quarterly, or annually. In the Standing Committee, the President promised that he would, so far as he could, alter the terms of compensation in order to ensure that those in respect of weekly wage earners were similar to those for persons earning salaries. When the Amendment was put on the Order Paper we had not had the information that the President had made an alteration. That information was given yesterday in reply to a sponsored Question from an hon. Member opposite.
I move the Amendment to give the President an opportunity to explain the altered provisions for compensation, so that we may be certain that they fulfil the promises made in the Standing Committee.
I beg to second the Amendment.

I welcome the fact that the hon. Lady the Member for Liverpool, Exchange (Mrs. Braddock) put down this Amendment, which gives me the opportunity of saying that I have given full consideration to the discussion which we had on this subject in the Standing Committee. Though the compensation scheme, as such, is not before us, but only the Clause which gives power for the Commission to draw up and submit a scheme, we have, I think properly, had some discussion about it.
Amongst the points which have been raised has been the one that, in calculating the compensation, arrangements might be made to treat the members of the staff who are paid weekly on the same basis as those who are paid monthly. I am not going to argue the philosophical merits of that suggestion. No doubt, there are some cases in which one should, and others in which one should not, but, on looking into the matter, I find that the total cost to public funds is not very large. I think the cost of the alteration is about £10,000—not a large amount. It does seem right that we should have asked the Commission to look at it again, and I would point out that it is the Commission which has to submit a scheme.
They have submitted a new scheme in the terms which I announced in answer
to a Question yesterday by one of my hon. Friends. Without going into the precise terms, I think it will suffice for me to inform the House that the new arrangements, for the gratuities paid and so forth, place the weekly wage earners on exactly the same terms in regard to compensation as those who are paid monthly or by reference to any other period.

I assure the right hon. Gentleman that, for reasons which are now obvious, we do not intend to press the Amendment to a Division, and in view of the rapidly diminishing size of the Government's majority in previous Divisions this evening, I think that the right hon. Gentleman will, by the assurance which I have just given him, feel greatly relieved of the anxiety which he must have been feeling.
I wish to say, on behalf of the Opposition, how much we welcome this very narrow and small part of what otherwise is a very bad Bill, the President's change of heart and the spirit in which he has approached the suggestions which we put to him. I think it would be right to say, before congratulating him, that this has been a good day for my hon. Friend the Member for Liverpool, Exchange (Mrs. Braddock), who has played a leading part in the earlier debate this afternoon—at least, in giving rise to it—while the Amendment which we are now debating, and the President's assurance on it, represent the answer to the arguments which the hon. Lady and other Members of Standing Committee A deployed for some hours during our deliberations just after Christmas.
At that time, we felt that the Government's proposal to add this discrimination between monthly and weekly-paid wage earners was indefensible and inequitable. We could have saved some hours if the Government had seen the force of our arguments a little more quickly, but we were glad when the President said that he would think again about them.
His speech this evening and his answer to a Question yesterday by the hon. Member for Garston (Sir V. Raikes) make clear that he has fulfilled what we asked him to do in this respect as fully as we could wish. My hon. Friends will also feel some satisfaction at the right hon. Gentleman's agreement to count the
periods of service not in annual but in six-monthly periods. We should have liked him to have gone further, and I am sorry he has not done so, but for what he has done we express our appreciation.
On the main point that we put to him about monthly and weekly wage earners we feel we have achieved a concrete result for the length of time that was spent by hon. Members in the Standing Committee. This represents a partial retreat by the Government in their class warfare, on one narrow front. We are only too happy to welcome that small sign of grace. I assure the hon. Gentleman that we shall not take this argument much further on this Amendment, and that we shall not press the Amendment to a Division.

I thank the President of the Board of Trade for the statement that he has made. I think he will agree that the arguments put up by the Opposition in Committee have convinced him that the case is very strong indeed, or else he would not be taking the responsibility of recommending to the Commission that these alterations be made. In view of that, I beg to ask leave to withdraw the Amendment.
Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

publicwhip.major-heading: Orders of the Day — PROCEDURE OF THE HOUSE (EXCHEQUER EQUALISATION GRANTS)

speech.speakername: The Financial Secretary to the Treasury (Mr. John Boyd-Carpenter)
speech.p:
I beg to move,
That, in the case of a Bill (whether Public or Private) containing any provision which would or might operate to increase Exchequer Equalisation Grants in England or Wales, the Standing Orders and practice of this House relating to provisions authorising charges upon the public revenue shall not be deemed to apply to that provision by reason only of the consequential increase in Exchequer Equalisation Grants in Scotland under the Local Government (Financial Provisions) (Scotland) Act, 1954. [Queen's Recommendation signified.]
The need for this Motion arises from the fact that the Local Government (Financial Provisions) (Scotland) Act, 1954, has become law during the last few days. The effect of that is that equalisation grants payable to Scottish local
authorities are no longer fixed on the principles of the Local Government Act, 1948, but on the basis of the Goschen formula, that is to say, eleven-eightieths of similar expenditure in England and Wales. The consequence is that a proposal which can affect the total equalisation grants in England and Wales has the effect of increasing those grants in Scotland.
As the consequence of that, Money Resolutions, and indeed Bills, now before this House do not technically comply with the Standing Orders, inasmuch as authority is not provided for the consequential expenditure in Scotland. The Motion has the effect of correcting this position. It is drafted to cover Resolutions during the whole of this Session, as the comparable one which followed the passing of the Local Government Act, 1948, also did. The intention is that new Money Resolutions shall be drafted to comply with the new situation arising from the passing of the Scottish Act, and expenses Clauses of Bills before the House which are at a stage where this can be done will be amended consequently.
The motion is none the less drafted in this general form to cover Bills which are at too late a stage for those steps to be taken, and also to cover late-presented Private Bills. It covers the whole of the Session and it appears probable that in due course it will be necessary to make some minor alterations to Standing Orders.
Is this Motion to be discussed by the Scottish Standing Committee?
If I may, by leave of the House, reply to that question, this Motion is a proposal governing the procedure of the House, and, therefore, it has to be discussed in this House.
